I think if you brought the ferrofluid percentage down to 20-25%, and left more of the paraffin wax in the mixture it would have had more of the fluid dynamics of an original lamp with the globules actually moving up and down the lamp, still being translucent, but also retaining the magnetic effect of the fluid. also most lava lamps use an adhesive or seal when they put the cap on so, that could by why the seal wasn't amazing.

It’s not gonna move on it’s on what so ever or be a lamp now , I mean sure fun with a magnet but not visible and will not move like normal wax in a lava lamp . Lava lamps are tricky … trust me redoing mine was a mother f.. still cool but totally just ferrofluid in liquid

Wanted to say that it isn’t just hot and cold how lava lamps work , trying to get the correct density of epsom salt and distilled water with a few other things is actually not that easy and takes alot of time .

I feel like the lamp itself is missing the brightness I would expect from a lava lamp and I think it should have been done with a brighter colored fluid, at least for the purpose of demonstration. It feels a little hard to be excited for a dull colored lava lamp. Maybe a clear or yellow fluid would have helped show off the ferrofluid properties better and helped with the penetration of light through the rest of the lamp. The studio lighting also resembled the lamp color and I think it blended through.

It's a magnificent idea, but this was not a well produced showcase of the Ferrofluid Lava Lamp. I'd love to see you revisit this idea in the future and improve upon it some more!
